post.message:
Hi Roman, I really like this post. Narrow and simple 3 points with nice images :) I just had to read it.

I think this content would deserve more attention.
Would you be interested in respoting on Pehapkari blog?
It runs on Statie as well, so it could not be simpler :)

If so, just send PR and I'll get to it right away.

---

Btw, what is your motivation to hide comments under the post? I always have to click to see or write one and it takes a while :/

Hey Roman, thanks for this post. I like every little improvement forward.

I've added the post to official docs, so people can find right away: https://github.com/Symplify...

If you got any similar posts in the future about, just send PR.
Thanks for sharing, Tomas, hopefully it'd be helpful for someone. And sure, will definitely do!

I'm happy you like it :) and yes, I'll provide you PR soon, looking forward what others will say.

---

I don't like to load unnecessary stuff until it's really needed. Or I at least try to do so. Now I need to think about displaying a comments count :) but probably also rethink the solution in the future.

I don't like to load unnecessary stuff until it's really needed.

I think that's not the case. At least I do need comments to my posts as form of feedback and interest and great ideas how to do it event better.

I wanted to reply last time, but could not find these comment at all :D probably due to migration to Statie 3, if I saw that corretly.

I'm glad it work now .)

They had some kind of error in Netlify (where I host my site) - several files weren't accessible, *.js among them.

If it will be the case in the future that many people start to add comments under articles somehow I'll probably rethink this solution :)

I see. Only A/B testing can help there.

Btw, how would you compare Netlify to Github pages? What are the differences? I see it for Netlify thanks to you for the first time, so I'd like to know more.

Well, among other things, you can set custom domain with ssl certificate effortlessly, which was a big deal for me.
Concurrent builds for all branches is also a nice feature.
Recently I also used an option to set custom redirects on another project.
You said A/B testing? Also possible!
And there are tons of other features https://www.netlify.com/fea... and what's the best? Everything is for free :)

(one con is that you cannot run Statie there, because of PHP version which is available in the image. So I build this web in Travis and then send it as a zip file to Netlify)

Sounds like advanced hosting services :) cool, thanks for summing up.

I hope the PHP get resolved soon, so you don't need Travis for that.

Protip: you can use it also for shortcuts (not search, just direct link):
https://uploads.disquscdn.c...

I like this functionality. Thanks for writing about it.
I wish they had decided to use the text quote selector instead, as defined in the web annotation data model, which is a W3C recommendation since 2017. What do you think?

Thanks for your comment! To be honest, I haven't came across that specification before. From the glance, it seems much more powerful in comparison to the text fragments.
I can imagine that in the future they may work on the top of the annotation model you referenced...
Recently, I started tinkering in the waters of indieweb which has its own model for such kind of "mentions" - fragmentions. We have much to choose from.

I didn't know about Indieweb's fragmentions either.
I think the discussion here about Scroll to Text and W3C Web Annotation is worth reading: https://github.com/WICG/scr...
